metadata.titleEn: Energy, water vapor and carbon exchange observations in oasis-desert areas of Heihe river basin (2012-2021)
metadata.description:
Oases and deserts generally act as a landscape matrix and mosaic in arid/semiarid regions. An oasis is a unique ecological landscape in arid and semiarid areas, which is not only the core of its ecological environment but also the foundation of its economic development, especially in western China where has been an important part of the ‘Silk Road’ since ancient times. The particularity of the underlying surface in the oasis-desert area, e.g., the irrigation cropland, riparian forest, sandy vegetation, seasonal snow and frozen soil, makes the study of land‒atmosphere interactions complex and needs comprehensive consideration in such heterogeneous underlying surfaces.
  The Heihe River Basin (HRB), the second largest endorheic basin in China, is characterized by artificial oases and natural oases in the middle and lower reaches, respectively. We present a suite of observational datasets in artificial and natural oases-desert systems, which consist of long-term energy, water vapor, carbon/methane fluxes, and auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation and soil parameters from 2012 to 2021. Half-hourly turbulent flux data were acquired by an eddy covariance system and scintillometer. The hydrometeorological data, including radiation, soil heat flux and soil temperature profile, gradient of air temperature/humidity and wind speed/direction, air pressure, precipitation and soil moisture profiles, were observed from automatic weather stations with a 10-minute average period as well as the groundwater table data. Moreover, vegetation and soil parameters were also supplemented in the datasets. 
The up-to-date datasets have been released to scientists, and expected to give a quantitative understanding of the energy, water vapor and carbon exchange in oasis-desert areas is crucial for recognizing the oasis-desert interactions and is significant for protecting the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases, and long-term observations are indispensable.

background: Arid and semiarid regions represent approximately 30 % of the global terrestrial surface area (Dregne, 1991; Scanlon et al., 2006), and dryland expansion occurs under climate change, especially in developing countries (Huang et al., 2016). An oasis is a unique ecological landscape in arid and semi-arid areas that is not only the core of regions’ ecological environment but also the foundation of their economic development, especially in western China, which has been an important part of the “Silk Road” since ancient times. Oases comprising less than 10 % of the total area of arid regions support more than 90 % of the population in these regions of China (Chu et al., 2005; Li et al., 2016; Zhou et al., 2022). The oasis–desert system plays a crucial role in maintaining a stable ecological environment and agricultural productivity (Zhang and Zhao, 2015). Extensive studies have investigated energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas based on field and remote-sensing observations (Taha et al., 1991; Potchter et al., 2008; Xue et al., 2019; Wang et al., 2019; Zhou et al., 2022) and numerical simulations (Chu et al., 2005; Meng et al., 2009; Georgescu et al., 2011; Liu et al., 2020). In addition, oasis–desert areas located in semiarid regions have been found to be carbon sinks by previous researchers (Tagesson et al., 2016; Wang et al., 2019); thus, they can significantly affect the carbon balance of arid regions and play an increasingly important role within the global carbon cycle.
research objective: Therefore, it is critical to maintain the balance between oasis and desert systems in order to achieve the goal of sustainable oasis development. Understanding the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems is important to achieve the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality in the oasis–desert area and support the ecological security and sustainable development of the oasis. A quantitative understanding of the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas is crucial to recognize the oasis–desert interactions and is significant to protect the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases; moreover, long-term observations are indispensable.
challenges: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas are facing the crisis of ecological environment degradation, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, the degradation of natural vegetation, the intensification of land desertification, and the frequent occurrence of dust storms, especially in many inland river basins westward along the Silk Road, such as the Tarim River basin (Zhao et al., 2013), the Aral Sea basin (Stanev et al., 2004; Crétaux et al., 2009), and the Lake Urmia basin (Stone, 2015).
methods: In this study, we present a suite of observational datasets from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems that consist of long-term energy, water vapor, carbon and methane fluxes as well as auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters from 2012 to 2021. Half-hourly turbulent flux data were acquired by an eddy covariance system and scintillometer. The hydrometeorological data (including radiation, soil heat flux, and soil temperature profiles; gradients of air temperature and humidity and of wind speed and direction; and air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles) were observed from automatic weather stations with a 10 min average period as well as the groundwater table data. Moreover, vegetation and soil parameters were also supplemented in the datasets. The data processing and quality control procedure can be divided into data collection, data processing, and data archiving and sharing.
dataset: The study area comprises the middle and lower reaches of the HRB, located in the arid regions of western China, that receive water from the typical cryosphere of the upper reaches. A total of 11 land surface flux and meteorological stations have been established in these regions since 2012 – 2 superstations and 9 ordinary stations. The dataset of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange observations in oasis–desert areas reported in this study (including energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes; hydrometeorological data; and vegetation and soil parameters) is freely available from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center.

Definition.Question: What is an eddy covariance system in the context of data collection for oasis-desert ecosystems?
Definition.Answer: An eddy covariance system is a data collection method used to acquire half-hourly turbulent flux data, including energy, water vapor, carbon, and methane fluxes. This system helps in understanding the exchange processes of these elements in oasis-desert ecosystems.

Definition.Question: What does data processing and quality control entail in the context of long-term observational datasets from oasis-desert systems?
Definition.Answer: Data processing and quality control in this context involve the steps of data collection, data processing, and data archiving and sharing to ensure the reliability and accuracy of the observational datasets, which include energy, water vapor, carbon fluxes, and other auxiliary data.

Comparison.Question: In what ways do the auxiliary data involving vegetation and soil parameters complement the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange datasets in oasis–desert ecosystems, compared to standalone flux measurements?
Comparison.Answer: Auxiliary data involving vegetation and soil parameters complement flux measurements by providing context and understanding of the underlying biological and physical processes affecting energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange. This additional information helps in interpreting flux data more accurately, as it accounts for factors like vegetation cover and soil moisture, which influence the fluxes.

Interpretation.Question: What underlying interactions can be inferred from the long-term observations of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Interpretation.Answer: The long-term observations provide a quantitative understanding of the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas, which is crucial for recognizing oasis–desert interactions and significant for protecting the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases.

Interpretation.Question: What challenges can be identified in the data collection process for hydrometeorological parameters in arid regions?
Interpretation.Answer: Arid and semiarid inland river basins face ecological environment degradation, such as drying rivers, degraded natural vegetation, intensified land desertification, and frequent dust storms, which pose challenges in collecting reliable hydrometeorological data.

Interpretation.Question: How do the data collection methods using eddy covariance systems and scintillometers contribute to understanding carbon fluxes in oasis–desert areas?
Interpretation.Answer: Eddy covariance systems and scintillometers provide half-hourly turbulent flux data, which contribute to understanding the carbon fluxes by capturing detailed energy, water vapor, and carbon/methane fluxes that are crucial for analyzing the carbon balance and interactions within oasis–desert ecosystems.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the complexity of studying land-atmosphere interactions in oasis-desert regions?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The complexity of studying land-atmosphere interactions in oasis-desert regions arises from the heterogeneity of the underlying surfaces, such as irrigated farmland, riparian forests, sandy vegetation, seasonal snow, and permafrost. These diverse landscapes require comprehensive consideration in research approaches.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is long-term observation essential for understanding energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis-desert systems?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Long-term observation is essential for understanding energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis-desert systems to capture the temporal dynamics and interactions between the oasis and desert environments. This is crucial for recognizing these interactions and their implications for ecological stability and socioeconomic development.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What challenges arise in the collection and processing of hydrometeorological data in arid and semiarid inland river basins?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Challenges in the collection and processing of hydrometeorological data in arid and semiarid inland river basins include dealing with ecological environment degradation, such as river and lake drying, natural vegetation degradation, land desertification, and frequent dust storms, which complicate data collection and quality control.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the possible outcomes of utilizing an eddy covariance system and scintillometer for collecting half-hourly turbulent flux data in oasis-desert ecosystems?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Utilizing an eddy covariance system and scintillometer can lead to precise measurements of energy, water vapor, carbon, and methane fluxes in oasis-desert ecosystems. This approach provides detailed insights into the exchange processes between the land surface and the atmosphere, which is crucial for understanding the interactions within these unique ecological landscapes. Such detailed data can support the goals of carbon peaking and neutrality, as well as ecological security and sustainable development.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the primary objective of collecting long-term energy, water vapor, and carbon data in oasis-desert ecosystems?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objective is to achieve a quantitative understanding of the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis-desert areas, which is crucial for recognizing oasis-desert interactions. This understanding is significant for protecting the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases, and for achieving the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality in these ecosystems.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to maintain a balance between oasis and desert systems in arid and semiarid regions?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Maintaining a balance between oasis and desert systems is important in order to achieve sustainable oasis development. This balance supports the ecological security and sustainable development of the oasis, which is crucial due to the role oases play in supporting over 90% of the population in these regions despite comprising less than 10% of the total area.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the intended benefits of conducting long-term observations in oasis-desert areas?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Long-term observations are intended to provide an in-depth and quantitative understanding of the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis-desert areas. These benefits are essential for recognizing the interactions between oases and deserts, ensuring ecological stability, and fostering the socioeconomic development of oases.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How are long-term energy, water vapor, and carbon flux data collected and processed in arid and semi-arid oasis-desert ecosystems?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Half-hourly turbulent flux data are acquired using an eddy covariance system and scintillometer. Hydrometeorological data are collected from automatic weather stations with a 10-minute average period, including measurements of radiation, soil heat flux, soil temperature profiles, air temperature and humidity gradients, wind speed and direction, air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles, along with groundwater table data. The data collection process involves steps of data acquisition, processing, and archiving for sharing.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the key procedural steps in ensuring the quality and sharing of hydrometeorological and flux data from oasis-desert areas?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The data processing and quality control procedure involves data collection, processing, and archiving. The collected data include energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes, as well as hydrometeorological information and vegetation and soil parameters. The processed data are then made available for sharing, supporting the understanding of oasis-desert interactions and ecological stability.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What instrumentation and methodology are employed to measure soil heat flux and soil temperature profiles in oasis-desert ecosystems?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Soil heat flux and soil temperature profiles are measured using automatic weather stations. These stations collect data on a 10-minute average period, capturing gradients of various meteorological parameters. The instrumentation allows for detailed observations necessary for understanding the energy exchange processes in oasis-desert ecosystems.

Enablement.Question: What observational technologies enable the comprehensive collection of energy, water vapor, and carbon flux data in oasis-desert ecosystems?
Enablement.Answer: The comprehensive collection of energy, water vapor, and carbon flux data in oasis-desert ecosystems is enabled by technologies such as eddy covariance systems and scintillometers, which acquire half-hourly turbulent flux data. Additionally, automatic weather stations provide hydrometeorological data, including radiation, soil heat flux, soil temperature profiles, air temperature and humidity gradients, wind speed and direction, air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles on a 10-minute average basis.

Enablement.Question: How does the integration of various hydrometeorological data collection methods enable a better understanding of oasis-desert interactions?
Enablement.Answer: The integration of various hydrometeorological data collection methods, such as automatic weather stations that observe radiation, soil heat flux, and soil temperature profiles, enables a better understanding of oasis-desert interactions by providing detailed and continuous measurements of environmental parameters. This comprehensive dataset supports the analysis of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges, essential for understanding the balance and interactions within oasis-desert ecosystems.

Enablement.Question: What conditions must be met to ensure the successful long-term observation of ecological stability in oasis-desert areas?
Enablement.Answer: The successful long-term observation of ecological stability in oasis-desert areas requires conditions such as the establishment of a network of land surface flux and meteorological stations, including superstations and ordinary stations, to collect diverse datasets over extended periods. Additionally, maintaining rigorous data processing and quality control procedures, as well as ensuring data archiving and sharing, are crucial for generating reliable insights into the ecological stability of these regions.

Expectation.Question: Why might there be a need for long-term observational datasets to understand energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis-desert ecosystems?
Expectation.Answer: A quantitative understanding of the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas is crucial for recognizing the interactions between these systems. Long-term observations are indispensable to protect the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases, contributing to the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality.

Expectation.Question: What challenges might researchers face when collecting data in arid and semiarid inland river basins, and how might these affect expected outcomes?
Expectation.Answer: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas are facing the crisis of ecological environment degradation, such as drying up rivers and lakes, degradation of natural vegetation, intensification of land desertification, and frequent dust storms. These issues can complicate data collection and affect the reliability and consistency of the expected outcomes.

Expectation.Question: Why is the integration of various data types, such as hydrometeorological data and vegetation parameters, crucial for understanding oasis-desert interactions in dataset collection?
Expectation.Answer: Integrating various data types such as hydrometeorological data and vegetation and soil parameters is crucial for a comprehensive understanding of oasis-desert interactions. This approach allows for a more detailed analysis of the complex land-atmosphere interactions specific to these heterogeneous landscapes and supports sustainable development by maintaining the balance between oasis and desert systems.

Judgmental.Question: How would you evaluate the effectiveness of using eddy covariance systems and scintillometers in capturing accurate energy, water vapor, and carbon flux data in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Judgmental.Answer: The use of eddy covariance systems and scintillometers is crucial for capturing half-hourly turbulent flux data, which is essential for understanding the complex interactions in oasis–desert ecosystems. These methods are effective because they provide detailed temporal data on energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes, which are key to understanding the ecological and socioeconomic dynamics in these areas.
